comments.commentBody: Sorry. Edit. That was supposed to start "I agree the US ought not to jump into Ukraine."

If you read "The Barbarous Years: by Bernard Bailyn" you will find that the religious freedom fabrication was not so free unless you were a member of that religion.

For instance we think of Quakers as being peaceful hard working people. But in New England, they challenged the Puritan view, and some were hanged for it. Later in the 19th century, the Irish were regarded as barbarians, and Catholicism was considered to be threat to the American way.

Under Queen Elizabeth, Catholics were executed, but that was after Queen Mary executed Protestants. The Puritans were not wanted in England or Holland as they were accused of undermining the Anglican Church. Read 'Hellfire Nation: by James A. Morone."
The Idea of religious freedom in America is a fantasy.

@GSamsa - The method theoretically allows prospective parents who can afford it, to prevent such blindness by using the new technique. (That's a great thing in my mind.) However, it is unlikely to be affordable to all, and as you can tell by the comments here, many people think it is unethical to make any changes to an embryo, even if it means bringing a sick child into the world. For such prospective parents, accepting to bring a child who is going to be blind into this world is hardly the same as intentionally inflicting harm on a living child that has been born. Your argument seems to suggest that parents have an obligation to prevent a child from being born with any handicap.

"Since 2003, the rate for youths over all — ages 2 to 19 — has remained flat"

did you miss this or are you saying the recession only hit the under 2 set?

From the 8th paragraph: "Barry M. Popkin (...) said families with children had been buying lower-calorie foods over the past decade, a pattern he said was unrelated to the economic downturn."

Also, there have been many news stories about McDonald's doing very well during the Great Recession. Their food is cheap, but it's not exactly low in calories.

For S.A. - I think that would imply that the 2-5 set is a vast minority in the overall youth set (2-19) and should also imply that obesity rates have risen in some other group in order for there to be absolutely no change overall despite a "43% decrease" in the 2-5 range.
It is amazing that the Great Recession is not mentioned as a factor in reduced calorie intake. How convenient.
Thank you for your spot-on comment.  You are absolutely correct about all of it.
Sorry, I have no sympathy for the other "Mr. Katz," the one who defamed a dead person.

He didn't "ad lib what turned out to be jokes."  He slandered someone grieving the unexpected death of a friend.  He could have said that they had the wrong guy.  But he didn't.  He wanted to see what he could do to Mr. Bar Katz.  Now he may suffer.  Sorry if I lack sympathy.

The end of the story is very disturbing, and I implore Mr. Burstein to reconsider. In today's world relentless litigation could indeed bankrupt somebody who apparently answered the phone and ad-libbed what turned out to be jokes so outrageous that only the National Enquirer would fall for them.

Is bankrupting this person really what Mr. Hoffman would have wanted? Please reconsider.
@Dan:  Anyone who believes of the Enquirer that "they are the professionals" should be automatically disqualified from *any* jury on the basis of insufficient grasp of reality.
Forgive me, but I have no sympathy for the......God, I can barely say its name........ national enquirer.  Thy doth protest too much.
The National Enquirer has been publishing this kind of stuff since 1957.  Bad information didn't start with the internet.
Hear, Hear!

This is a game of chess, not checkers. Afghanistan is a breeding ground for terrorists, and was so before we got involved. Next door is Pakistan, which is just about as ungovernable with the added bonus of having nuclear weapons. The US has to have some presence in this area because it's in our security interests to do so. Look how well it worked for us when we weren't there.

Keep your friends close, and your enemies closer.
Sun-tzu

Why does the United States insist on dancing this dance?  I am a proud liberal with a sense of duty to all human beings.  But why would the USA remain in a country where their presence is unwelcome?  Why would the USA risk even one more American life?  Get out, NOW.  The very sad reality is that Afghanistan has not changed much in the last 1,000 years and most likely won't change much in the next 1,000 years.  Bring home the young men and women you, Mr. President, have suffered to remain in that desert.  Honestly, we could use the expertise and funding to address issues at home.

Perhaps "Obviously" is too strong a word, but the writer has a point; It is already well-established that the Chinese government has used thugs to do its dirty work. If the CCP were in the West, you can be sure it would be under police investigation regarding this assault.

You're kidding, right, "Hypocrisy"? A description of how something "appears" in context is not the same as "guilty until proven innocent." It is implicitly and correctly a demand that any credible police investigation must address this "obvious" likelihood. I mean, a murderous assault on a journalist who stood up to the CCP, but hey, let's not jump to conclusions? Really? OK, no conclusions, not yet, how about is it OK to voice some suspicions?

I have no idea how realistic it is to expect a genuinely independent police investigation. But as for "facts," there is a cornucopia of facts already about the CCP's despotic control and violent intimidation of all media that publish contrary political views, as Carolyn says. But gee, maybe it was something else here. Maybe. Maybe Elvis is still alive too.
i do not belive this is a triad attack however

Obviously a Triad attack done with the encouragement/cooperation of the Chinese communist party.
Interesting how Triads in HK consider themselves patriotic enforcers and how the CCP always has campaigns on the Mainland to "strike hard" at organized crime organizations.
Hong Kong has been going downhill now for several years politically, environmentally and politically and it's just a matter of a few years before it is marginalized to just another low tiered Chinese city.

@C New York, N.Y.: Your arguments are based on a misunderstanding. Having above average income is not rich. $70,000 per year is not rich. $140,000 per year for two earners is not rich, though it is comfortably well off if you live in a relatively cheap area. "Rich" means more than being able to afford to eat out frequently and hire someone to clean once a week, though those are indicators of a comfortable income. Talking to the households who are poor is not a criterion for what is "rich", though it is all relative. To me, "rich" implies -- for example -- that you can *easily* afford to fly first class and go to expensive doctors.

One dictionary's definition: " having a great deal of money or assets; wealthy".

Any money one pays to the government is considered a "tax" by SCOTUS.
A traffic ticket fine is in actuality a tax on driving faster than the limit, for example.

By, in the case of ACA, it's very easy to avoid that federal tax. Just buy health insurance and, poof, no tax!

Actually EC, Using your incorrect analysis, you would then call Obamacare a penalty for being a citizen of the US.  A speeding ticket is a fine (penalty) not a tax.  You have a choice on driving over the speed limit or not.  You do demonstrate our point.  With Obamacare you have no choice.  You must buy healthcare.  You don't have to speed.  You haven't read anything about Obamacare.  They even admit the young population group has to subsidies the others for Obamacare to work.

It's nice to see articles about the Affordable Care Act as a tax.  Because that is exactly what the Supreme Court called it, a tax.  Funny how no one in practice actually calls it a tax.  They call it everything else but a tax.  How did the Supreme Court extrapolate that this was really going to be a tax when in actuality and in practice it's not treated as a tax?  How are politicians making these tax policy changes without the actual authority to unilaterally make tax policy by themselves?  So if we are truly going to call this a tax then the best name for this tax would be the "United States Citizen Tax".

Howie Your big time SPORK

and Elke ,
Not to be a SNAIL about this-Ruth Margolin is now on my LIST, her puzzle added SPICE to my eve.

Even though we have ICE and SKICAPS, R. and I no longer ASPIRE to make ASCENTS , and will LET others run AMOK up mountains.
Actually had at first "drug addict" for 11D :( , but then did fit the ADDICT into 46D .
Admirable how the constructionIST got POMPOUSASSIST and STARKISTNAKED in - my favorite answers :)))
Leapy- thanks for the reminder about "ICE Warriors".
Dayo, Dayo
RandE

Mark,
I gotta tell you about Quash, the son of a major property owner, who owned half of Kiawah Island after the War, Arnoldus Vanderhorst IV, whose family were considered to set Charleston's finest table. (Their house still stands in town!) When he died, the legitimate sons were passed over by the family, who selected Quash to lead the rebuilding and put him in charge of widely scattered holdings. His aunt called Quash, the Cassique of Kiawah! (Cassique was the term for the leader of the Kiawah native Americans, the islands namesake.)

Many of Quash's letters survive. He gives an account to the widow, "Ms. Adele" of the progress, asks after everyone's health, reports on current affairs (hot topics!), lays out his plans and steps--and once admonishes his brother for failing to deliver the items in the quantities he requested!

Quash's grandson later became a judge in New York. He is a noted local ghost, often seen walking the grounds with "he pa" (his daddy)!
You think the Southern slave owners feared a revolt more than the Northern slave owners?

Possibly slightly off topic but nonetheless related - Look at Haiti - a successful slave rebellion - the enslaved freed themselves and then France billed them for their losses, the US did not support their drive to freedom, self determination and democracy because they were afraid of the influence on America's own suffering enslaved.

Haiti has suffered since then because Haiti committed the unthinkable to those who profit from the blood trade- Haiti freed herself, and she has never been forgiven for it.

Since I had gone to school with Blacks, Asians, South Sea Islanders, and other minorities, I and several of others of us, who had been sent to Biloxi for USAF schooling, were astonished at the treatment of the Negroes in the south. We had no idea such conditions existed. This was in the early 1950s, and Jim Crow was in charge there.

Later when the civil rights movement began to gather force, and the killing, beating, police brutality was finally shown on national TV, we wondered, what kept these people from taking taking up arms and fighting back. Most of the people I knew at that time would have done so, if they had be so treated.

You have to give credit to the Civil Rights leadership for that no happening. It would have been a real war, and people like Medgar Evers, and M.L. King deserve a great deal fro keeping these movements non violent.

It is not hard to understand the actions of Denmark Vesey. It was one of the things the southern whites dreaded, a slave revolt. They were constantly working to stop any event that might lead to one.

The rhetoric of the time portrayed blacks as savages, who would despoil the purity of the southern bells, at the first opportunity. In their view, the white race was at risk if Negros got their freedom. Of course they did not worry about the purity of the plantation owners who managed to sire a few more slaves.

She, not he. Louise Antony.

You need to be thinking about human culture -- the well from which most of our beliefs are drawn. These are the things we don't even think about, because we've been so thoroughly enculturated.

I'm always surprised by anybody who asks, as you seem to, how there can be anything like altruism, moral behavior, ethics . . . without religion. The answer is that these things are embedded in culture and may or may not involve theistic religion. It's obvious to anybody who looks around the globe that you don't need religion or a God to tell you how to behave, what's good, what's evil, and all the rest. Religious people don't seem to understand this, but perhaps if they took Anthro 1 and paid attention, they would.

I don't feel like he ever really explained why he is an atheist instead of an agnostic. Also I would like someone who has a purely atheistic world view to explain what are the basis for his moral view. if we are all evolutionary products why should I give of my self interest for anything. The human species survival shouldn't obligate me in anything since there real right and wrong if we are just more advanced animals.

I find this, and the prior installment, disturbing in the logical flaws in each man's position. Here Mr. Anthony pins his atheism on the presence of evil, that "an omnipotent and benevolent being" wouldn't have created the world the way he is. Who said God was benevolent? That's just the common mythology, and not even so common as people think. The God of the Old Testament wasn't a cuddly God. You know, that whole killing 99.9999% of humanity in one fell swoop, having fathers give over their daughters to savages, that sort of thing. This is simply saying that God can't exist because the God I would like to exist would have done things differently, i.e. the way I want them to be done.

Last week we had the proof that God exists because we exist (If conditions in the Big Bang were .001% different the Universe wouldn't exist as we know it), and we wonder about God. This is simply God exists because I think God exists, and absolutely nothing more.

The only people who understand faith less than the atheists are the believers, and vice versa.

If we begin any discussion about God and Religion becomes the main focus then any argument about the existence of God is lost, for God has never been and will never be a religion.

We all have the free will to choose as to whether or not we believe that there is a God or there isn’t. Fact of the matter in the like manner that life is not a problem to be solved but a mystery to be lived and love, can never be explained but only experienced, so it is with God. No one can explain God to another in order for them to believe. God simply put could never be explained, God can only be experienced!

I survived deadly cancer in 1996 and that very year I fell into a coma and according to Medical Science I was never going to survive the cancer or wake up from the coma. However, after six days and six nights laying in a coma I woke up on the seventh day and not only did wake up from the coma, but the cancer that was logged in my spinal cord was no more!

People can believe or not believe about the things I saw whilst in the coma. I have never tried even in the slightest to use my experience in any manner whatsoever to interject belief into anyone. People find believe or non-belief from deep within.

About God not being a Religion this is my explanation;

http://sheriffali.com/2012/08/04/the-triune-god-is-not-a-religion/

About my cancer and being in a coma this is my explanation;

http://sheriffali.com/2012/08/21/what-i-saw-whie-i-was-in-a-coma/

In many instances (for human and many non-human species), cooperation among individuals aids the survival of each individual or their progeny. Self  interest does not always equate with individualism.

Sashka, this is a very common argument, and rather than dealing withit in terms of logic and philosophy, maybe you should look around you.  In the world we live in, do people who don't care to think about the existence of God (atheists, agnostics, indifferent, "fallen away") much worse as a group than those who believe in God as the source of morality?  They should be out stealing and murdering, but they aren't.  LIkewise Christian and Islamic fanatics who beilieve deeply in God are quite capable of loathsome crimes of every kind.  The reason is that morality inheres in our human society, our natures as primates, our natural impulses to love our friends and children and to obey group rules -- and this can extend finally to the whole human world. God and religion-based morality can't do better.

Sashka, I was raised a Jew and lost my faith when a rabbi berated me for asking about evolution during Hebrew school class when I was fourth grader. I became a full atheist when I learned that my feelings about God actually had a name, sometime in junior high.

As I'm now 42, that's a long time to think about and practice morality. Basically, it's this: I am a good and moral person because I believe it's necessary to society, beneficial to my own mental and physical health, and because of my duty to family. I volunteer in my children's schools and in the wider community (many of my church-going peers do not); I do not lie, cheat or steal (aren't most members of Congress religious?); and I'm at peace with myself. I really don't think that bringing God into my personal equation would make me a better person. Instead, I find that practicing morality without the presence of God is a more pure expression than being moral because of any external faith.

don't feel like she ever really explained why she is an atheist instead of an agnostic. Also I would like someone who has a purely atheistic world view to explain what are the basis for their moral view. if we are all evolutionary products why should I give of my self for anything. The human species survival shouldn't obligate me in anything since there is no real right and wrong if we are just a more advanced animal.

This graph has two other interesting features. Between 2001 and 2009 (roughly) there is a steady rise in the fraction of government spending from 31% to 33%. Between 1992 and 2000 (roughly) there is a steady decline in this percentage, from 34% to 31%.

Of course, we all know exactly who was President during those two periods of time. I would like to know the underlying mechanism causing those two slopes. Can we trace them to specific policies of the Federal government? Or to some other social or economic trends?

For anyone who dealt with developing countries, it is obvious that Karzai was looking for a final Swiss bank deposit and a guarantee of security.  Obama decided that he had enough and will allow Karzai to deal with being an unprotected private citizen in a turbulent region.  As for troops, it is America's interest to leave a residual force to stamp out terrorists and serve as a check to Pakistan and Iran.  Hopefully, the next Afghan leader will get it.
Great comment that provides additional context on the history of the black community in Charleston in the decades preceding the Civil War.  Thank you.

A portion of the official trial transcript from the court proceedings that sentenced Vesey, Peter Poyas, Gullah Jack Pritchard and 32 others to hang, and then be buried unmarked graves is available at:
"A Glory Over Everything:" History's Invisible Veil: [http://wp.me/p1mBVu-Rl], beginning at p. 24. (Scroll down to embedded scribd document, then enlarge.)

The overall ebook describes several Charleston families headed by black women, enslaved and free, whose children rose to prominence: the Cordoza brothers, Thomas and Francis, one who founded public education in Mississippi, the other whose name is on a DC high school; the Grimke brothers, nephews of the Grimke sisters (Sarah and Angelina), one who attended Harvard, the other Princeton Seminary, both forceful leaders.

It also details the overlooked story of one of the greatest and most engaged black abolitionist, Robert Purvis, born in Charleston during slavery, who became President of Pennsylvania's Anti-Slavery Society and a prominent contemporary of Garrison and others, and using his own house, helping more than 9,000 enslaved to escape along the Underground Railroad.

In the cruelty of slavery, many marriages existed across plantations; movement was permitted for family time.
Thank you for this post, Walter! I will definitely make it a point to visit the statue when I am in Charleston, and learn the African American experience of history there.

The memorial at "Mother" Emanuel AME Church to Denmark Vesey, after the cherubs of Raphael depicts 4 faces of black youths; I have polished their stone. The inscription says Vesey "struck a blow for liberation." The city's enslaved knew well freedom's path.

In 1817, over 3,000 black Methodists, enslaved/free, walked out of Sunday services and founded the Bethel circuit; led by Morris Brown. that congregation by published accounts, gathered 3,000 for night worship. Bethel burned after Vesey's plot, but the city's mayor (Hutchinson) helped Brown and others reach Philadelphia. By 1849, within eyesight of the Citadel, defending the city after Vesey, Zion Presbyterian, built for an all-African congregation--had the largest sanctuary in the city.

In Avery's archives, by letter, the mayor requests meetings with Mr. Holloway, a black leader; blacks wrote to protest a lost burial site. They established burial societies (The Brown Fellowship/the Brotherhood) and schools (Daniel A Payne bio, Anson St.) before freedom, and ample evidence shows Charleston's urban enslaved ran businesses, worked and received wages!

Weekly, the newspaper advertises for "Negro hires" in all crafts and jobs--mixed with the ads for runaways. An enslaved of Nathaniel Russell, a leading merchant, ran a blacksmith shop and hired whites! Enslaved women ran the city's fish market; those in the country sold vegetables to the city. All kept their proceeds.

And Vesey was no more violent than Colin Powell.

T.Z., didn't the Liberals hate and fear President Bush - even before he was sworn in?
Decide what percentage of achiever's taxes would be enough and get back to us. Right now, state & federal bites can add up to over 55% for some people. Polling generally settles on around 20%.

Steve in Kentucky:

"Achievers"??

I guess "job creators" didn't fly nor did "makers" so now you or someone has come up with "achievers." Beautiful. As if achievement is only measured in dollars and cents. Silly me, I forgot. For Republicans it is.

Since Kentucky gets back about $1.52 in tax dollars for every tax dollar it sends to Washington can you tell the "achieving states" what percentage of their taxes it would be OK for you to take?
At last a robust explanation of the GOP's insistence that there is something amiss at the IRS, beyond the obvious that they hate having rich people's taxes collected and they fear and hate Obama.
